text.note: arXiv:1312.2484v3 [math-ph] 12 Mar 2014
text.front:
QUANTUM GROUPS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONS FOR HIGHER RANK
HERMANN BOOS, FRANK G ¨
OHMANN, ANDREAS KL
MPER,
KHAZRET S. NIROV, AND ALEXANDER V. RAZUMOV
ABSTRACT. A detailed construction of the universal integrability objects related to the
integrable systems associated with the quantum group U q (L(sl 3 )) is given. The full proof
of the functional relations in the form independent of the representation of the quantum
group on the quantum space is presented. The case of the general gradation and general
twisting is treated. The specialization of the universal functional relations to the case when
the quantum space is the state space of a discrete spin chain is described.

H. BOOS, F. G ¨
OHMANN, A. KL
MPER, KH. S. NIROV, AND A. V. RAZUMOV
text.body:
1. INTRODUCTION
The method of functional relations was proposed by Baxter to solve statistical models
which can or cannot be treated with the help of the Bethe ansatz, see, for example, [1, 2].
It appears that its main ingredients, transfer matrices and Q-operators, are essential not
only for the integration of the corresponding quantum statistical models in the sense of
calculating the partition function in the thermodynamic limit. One of the remarkable
recent applications is their usage in the construction of the fermionic basis [3–6] for the
observables of the XXZ spin chain.
It seems that the most productive, although not comprehensive, modern approach to
the theory of quantum integrable systems is the approach based on the concept of quan-
tum group invented by Drinfeld and Jimbo [7, 8]. In accordance with this approach, the
transfer matrices and Q-operators are constructed by choosing first the representations
for the factors of the tensor product of two copies of the underlying quantum group.
Then these representations are applied to the universal R-matrix, and finally the trace
over one of the representation spaces is taken. Here the functional relations are conse-
quences of the properties of the used representations of the quantum group. For the first
time, it was conceived by Bazhanov, Lukyanov and Zamolodchikov [9–11].
Following the physical tradition, we call the representation space corresponding to the
first factor of the tensor product the auxiliary space, and the representation space corre-
sponding to the second factor the quantum space. The representation on the auxiliary
space defines the integrability object, while the representation on the quantum space de-
fines the concrete physical integrable system. It appears convenient for our purposes to
fix the representation for the first factor only, see, for example, [12–16]. We use for the
objects obtained in such a way the term " universal " . The relations obtained for them can
be used for any physical model related to the quantum group under consideration.
In the papers [9–11] the case of the quantum group U q (L(sl 2 )) was considered and
as the quantum space the state space of a conformally invariant two dimensional field
theory was taken. We reconsidered the case of this quantum group in the papers [15, 16]
where we obtained the functional relations in the universal form and then chose as the
quantum space the state space of the XXZ-spin chain.
A two dimensional field theory with extended conformal symmetry related to the
quantum group U q (L(sl 3 )) was analysed in the paper [17]. Here as the quantum space
the corresponding state space of the quantum continuous field theory under considera-
tion was taken again. In the present paper we define for the case of the quantum group
U q (L(sl 3 )) universal integrability objects and derive the corresponding functional rela-
tions. Here to define the integrability objects we use the general gradation and general
twisting. However, the main difference from [17] is that we give a new and detailed
proof of the functional relations. In the paper [17] proofs are often skipped, or given in
schematic form. This was one of the reasons for writing our paper. Another reason was
the desire to have the specialization of the universal functional relations to the case when
the quantum space is the state space of a discrete spin chain.

We denote by L(g) the loop Lie algebra of a finite dimensional simple Lie algebra g and by
L(g) its standard central extension, see, for example, the book by Kac [18]. The symbol N
means the set of natural numbers and the symbol Z + the set of non-negative integers.

To construct integrability objects one uses spectral parameters. They are introduced
by defining a Z-gradation of the quantum group. In the case under consideration a Z-
gradation of U q (L(sl 3 )) is determined by three integers s 0 , s 1 and s 2 . We use the notation
s = s 0 + s 1 + s 2 and denote by r s some fixed sth root of −1, so that (r s ) s = −1.
2. INTEGRABILITY OBJECTS
In this paper we consider integrable systems related to the quantum group U q (L(sl 3 )).
Depending on the sense of the " deformation parameter " q, there are at least three def-
initions of a quantum group. According to the first definition, q = exp ¯

C[[¯ h]]-algebra, in the second case a C(q)-algebra, and in the third case it is just a complex
algebra. We define the quantum group as a C-algebra, see, for example, the books [19,20].
To construct representations of the quantum group U q (L(sl 3 )) we use the Jimbo's ho-
momorphism from U q (L(sl 3 )) to the quantum group U q (gl 3 ). Therefore, we first remind
the definition of U q (gl 3 ) and then discuss U q (L(sl 3 )).

The expression for the universal R-matrix of U q (L(sl 3 )) considered as a C[[¯ h]]-algebra
can be constructed using the procedure proposed by Khoroshkin and Tolstoy [23]. Note
that here the universal R-matrix is an element of U q (b + ) ⊗ U q (b − ), where U q (b + ) is the
Borel subalgebra of U q (L(sl 3 )) generated by e i , i = 0, 1, 2, and q x , x ∈ h, and U q (b − ) is
the Borel subalgebra of U q (L(sl 3 )) generated by f i , i = 0, 1, 2, and q x , x ∈ h.
In fact, one can use the expression for the universal R-matrix from the paper [23] also
for the case of the quantum group U q (L(sl 3 )) defined as a C-algebra having in mind that
in this case the quantum group is quasitriangular only in some restricted sense. Namely,
all the relations involving the universal R-matrix should be considered as valid only for
the weight representations of U q (L(sl 3 )), see in this respect the paper [24] and the dis-
cussion below.
Recall that a representation ϕ of U q (L(sl 3 )) on the vector space V is a weight represen-
tation if

2.3. R-operators
To obtain R-operators, or, as they also called, R-matrices, one uses for both factors of the
tensor product of the two copies of the quantum group one and the same finite dimen-
sional representation. We do not use in this paper the explicit form of the R-operators
for the quantum group U q (L(sl 3 )). The corresponding calculations for this case and for
some other quantum groups can be found in the papers [22, 25–30].
text.note: QUANTUM GROUPS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONS FOR HIGHER RANK

2.4. Universal monodromy and universal transfer operators
2.4.1. General remarks. To construct universal monodromy and transfer operators we en-
dow U q (L(sl 3 )) with a Z-gradation, see, for example, [15, 16]. The usual way to do it is
as follows.
Given ζ ∈ C × , we define an automorphism Γ ζ of U q (L(sl 3 )) by its action on the gener-
ators of U q (L(sl 3 )) as
Γ ζ (q
x ) = q
x ,
Γ ζ (e i ) = ζ
s i e i ,
Γ ζ ( f i ) = ζ
−s i f i ,
where s i are arbitrary integers. The family of automorphisms Γ ζ , ζ ∈ C × , generates the
Z-gradation with the grading subspaces
U q (L(sl 3 )) m = {a ∈ U q (L(sl 3 )) | Γ ζ (a) = ζ
m a}.
Taking into account (2.16) we see that
(Γ ζ ⊗ Γ ζ ) • ∆ = ∆ • Γ ζ .
(2.27)
It also follows from the explicit form of the universal R-matrix obtained with the help of
the Tolstoy–Khoroshkin construction, see [22, 23], that for any ζ ∈ C × we have
(Γ ζ ⊗ Γ ζ )(R) = R.
(2.28)
Following the physical tradition, we call ζ the spectral parameter.
If π is a representation of U q (L(sl 3 )), then for any ζ ∈ C × the mapping π • Γ ζ is also a
representation of U q (L(sl 3 )) . Below, for any homomorphism ϕ from U q (L(sl 3 )) to some
algebra we use the notation
ϕ ζ = ϕ • Γ ζ .
(2.29)
If V is a U q (L(sl 3 ))-module corresponding to the representation π, we denote by V ζ the
U q (L(sl 3 ))-module corresponding to the representation π ζ . Certainly, as vector spaces V
and V ζ coincide.
Now let π be a representation of the quantum group U q (L(sl 3 )) on a vector space
V. The universal monodromy operator M π (ζ) corresponding to the representation π is
defined by the relation
M π (ζ) = (π ζ ⊗ id)(R).
It is clear that M π (ζ) is an element of End(V) ⊗ U q (L(sl 3 )).
Universal monodromy operators are auxiliary objects needed for construction of uni-
versal transfer operators. The universal transfer operator T π (ζ) corresponding to the
universal monodromy operator M π (ζ) is defined as
T π (ζ) = (tr ⊗id)(M π (ζ)(π ζ (t) ⊗ 1)) = ((tr •π ζ ) ⊗ id)(R(t ⊗ 1)),
where t is a group-like element of U q (L(sl 3 )) called a twist element. Note that T π (ζ) is an
element of U q (L(sl 3 )). An important property of the universal transfer operators T π (ζ)
is that they commute for all representations π and all values of ζ. They also commute
with all generators q x , x ∈ h, see, for example, our papers [15, 16].
As we noted above, to construct representations of U q (L(sl 3 )) we are going to use
Jimbo's homomorphism. It is a homomorphism ϕ : U q (L(sl 3 )) → U q (gl 3 ) defined by the
equations

being an element of U q (gl 3 ) ⊗ U q (L(sl 3 )). It is evident that
M π•ϕ (ζ) = (π ⊗ id)(M ϕ (ζ)) = ((π • ϕ ζ ) ⊗ id)(R).
For the corresponding transfer operator we have
T π•ϕ (ζ) = (tr ⊗id)(M π•ϕ (ζ)((π • ϕ ζ )(t) ⊗ 1)) = ((tr •π • ϕ ζ ) ⊗ id)(R(t ⊗ 1)).
Introduce the notation
tr π = tr •π.
Note that tr π is a trace on U q (gl 3 ). This means that it is a linear mapping from U q (gl 3 ) to
C satisfying the cyclicity condition
tr π (ab) = tr π (ba)
for any a, b ∈ U q (gl 3 ). One can write
T π•ϕ (ζ) = (tr ⊗id)(M π•ϕ (ζ)((π • ϕ ζ )(t) ⊗ 1)) = (tr π ⊗id)(M ϕ (ζ)(ϕ ζ (t) ⊗ 1)).
Thus, to obtain the universal transfer operators T π•ϕ (ζ), one can use different universal
monodromy operators M π•ϕ (ζ) corresponding to different representations π, or use one
and the same universal monodromy operator M ϕ (ζ) but different traces tr π correspond-
ing to different representations π.

The prime means that the corresponding homomorphisms and the objects related to them

2.4.4. Application of BGG resolution. Recall first some definitions and properties of the
necessary objects. We have denoted the standard Cartan subalgebra of the Lie algebra
gl 3 by g. The Weyl group W of the root system of gl 3 is generated by the reflections
r i : g * → g * , i = 1, 2, defined by the equation
r i (λ) = λ − λ(H i )α i .
The minimal number of generators r i necessary to represent an element w ∈ W is said to
be the length of w and is denoted by ℓ(w). It is assumed that the identity element has the
length equal to 0.
Let {γ i } be a dual basis of the standard basis {G i } of g. Using (2.1), it is easy to see that
α 1 = γ 1 − γ 2 ,
α 2 = γ 2 − γ 3 .
One can get convinced that
r 1 (γ 1 ) = γ 2 ,
r 1 (γ 2 ) = γ 1 ,
r 1 (γ 3 ) = γ 3 ,
r 2 (γ 1 ) = γ 1 ,
r 2 (γ 2 ) = γ 3 ,
r 2 (γ 3 ) = γ 2 .
Identifying an element of g * with the set of its components with respect to the basis
{γ i }, we see that the reflection r 1 transposes the first and second components, and r 2
transposes the second and third components. One can verify that the whole Weyl group
W can be identified with the symmetric group S 3 . Here (−1) ℓ(w) is evidently the sign of
the permutation corresponding to the element w ∈ W. The order of W is equal to six.
There are one element of length 0, two elements of length 1, two elements of length 2,
and one element of length 3.
Consider now a finite dimensional U q (gl 3 )-module V λ , see appendix A. Introduce the
following direct sums of infinite dimensional U q (gl 3 )-modules:

2.5. Universal L-operators and universal Q-operators
2.5.1. General remarks. It follows from (2.24) and (2.26) that to construct universal mon-
odromy operators and transfer operators it suffices to have a representation of the Borel
subalgebra U q (b + ). This observation is used to construct universal L-operators and Q-
operators. In distinction to the case of universal transfer operators, we use here rep-
resentations of U q (b + ) which cannot be obtained by restriction of representations of
U q (L(sl 3 )), or equivalently, representations of U q (b + ) which cannot be extended to rep-
resentations of U q (L(sl 3 )). It is clear that to have interesting functional relations one
should use for the construction of universal L-operators and Q-operators representations
which are connected in some way to the representations used for the construction of uni-
versal monodromy operators and transfer operators.
In general, a universal L-operator associated with a representation ρ of U q (b + ) is de-
fined as
L ρ (ζ) = (ρ ζ ⊗ id)(R).
As the universal monodromy operators are auxiliary objects needed for the construction
of the universal transfer operators, the universal L-operators are needed for the construc-
tion of the universal Q-operators. The universal Q-operator Q ρ (ζ) corresponding to the
universal L-operator L ρ (ζ) is defined as
Q ρ (ζ) = (tr ⊗id)(L ρ (ζ)(ρ ζ (t) ⊗ 1)) = ((tr •ρ ζ ) ⊗ id)(R(t ⊗ 1)),
where t is a twist element.
text.note: QUANTUM GROUPS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONS FOR HIGHER RANK
text.body:

3. FUNCTIONAL RELATIONS
3.1. Product of two universal Q-operators
The functional relations are some equations for products of transfer operators and Q-
operators. Consider the product of two universal Q-operators. In fact, one can consider
any pair of the universal Q-operators. The functional relations for other pairs are simple
consequences of the functional relations for the initial pair. It appears that the pair Q ′

4. SPIN CHAIN
4.1. Integrability objects
Let us start with a systematization of our zoo of universal integrability objects. There are
two types of them. An object of the first type is constructed using some homomorphism
from U q (L(sl 3 )) to some algebra A and the corresponding power of the automorphism σ.
These are the universal monodromy operators and the universal L-operators. We denote
a general representative of this type as X i (ζ). It is an element of A ⊗ U q (L(sl 3 )). More
concretely, we have a family of homomorphisms ω i such that
ω i+1 = ω i • σ
−1 ,

and define X i (ζ) as
X i (ζ) = ((ω i ) ζ ⊗ id)(R).
The objects of the second type are constructed from the objects of the first type by using
some trace tr A on the algebra A. These are the universal transfer operators and the uni-
versal Q-operators. We denote a general representative of the second type as Y i (ζ). It is
an element of U q (L(sl 3 )). We assume that
Y i (ζ) = (tr A ⊗id)(X i (ζ)((ω i ) ζ (t) ⊗ 1)),
(4.1)
where t ∈ U q (L(sl 3 )) is a twist element. In fact, due to the redefinition (3.5), it is not quite
so for the connection of the universal L-operators and the universal Q-operators. How-
ever, the necessary modification of (4.1) and of the further relations for the corresponding
integrability objects can be performed easily, see also the discussion below.
A concrete integrable model is defined by a choice of a representation for the second
factor of the tensor product U q (L(sl 3 )) ⊗ U q (L(sl 3 )). For the case of a spin chain one fixes
a finite dimensional representation ψ on the vector space U and defines the operators
X i (ζ|η 1 , . . . , η n ) = (id ⊗ (ψ η 1 ⊗ ∆ op · · · ⊗ ∆ op ψ η n ))(X i (ζ)),
(4.2)
Y i (ζ|η 1 , . . . , η n ) = (ψ η 1 ⊗ ∆ op · · · ⊗ ∆ op ψ η n )(Y i (ζ)),
(4.3)
associated with a chain of length n. Here, η 1 , . . ., η n are the spectral parameters associated
with the sites of the chain. It is clear that the operator X i (ζ|η 1 , . . . , η n ) is an element of
A ⊗ End(U) ⊗n and Y i (ζ|η 1 , . . . , η n ) is an element of End(U) ⊗n . It follows from (4.1) that
Y i (ζ|η 1 , . . . , η n ) = (tr A ⊗id)(X i (ζ|η 1 , . . . , η n )((ω i ) ζ (t) ⊗ 1)).
For all cases, except the case of Q-operators Q i (ζ|η 1 , . . . , η n ) and Q i (ζ|η 1 , . . . , η n ), using
equations (2.27) and (2.28), one can demonstrate that
X i (ζν|η 1 ν, . . . η n ν) = X i (ζ|η 1 , . . . , η n ),
Y i (ζν|η 1 ν, . . . η n ν) = Y i (ζ|η 1 , . . . , η n ) (4.4)
for any ν ∈ C × . In particular, for a one-site chain we have
X i (ζ|η) = X i (ζη
−1 ),
Y i (ζ|η) = Y i (ζη
−1 )
(4.5)
where X i (ζ) = X i (ζ|1) and Y i (ζ) = Y i (ζ|1), and we can write
X i (ζ|η) = (id ⊗ ψ)(X i (ζη
−1 )),
Y i (ζ|η) = ψ(Y i (ζη
−1 )).
(4.6)
Therefore, for one-site chains for all cases, except the case of the Q-operators, we define
integrability objects depending on one spectral parameter, having in mind that the corre-
sponding objects depending on two spectral parameters can be constructed by equations
of type (4.5).

5. CONCLUSIONS
We gave a detailed construction of the universal integrability objects related to the in-
tegrable systems associated with the quantum group U q (L(sl 3 )). The full proof of the
functional relations in the form independent of the representation of the quantum group
on the quantum space was presented. Generalizations to the case of the quantum group
U q (L(sl N )) and quantum supergroup U q (L(gl N|M ) are discussed in the papers [44] and
[45], respectively, however, mostly without proofs. However, the proofs for the case of
the quantum supergroup U q (L(sl 2|1 )) are given in [14]. A discussion of the functional
relations for the systems related to U q (L(sl 2 )) with q being a root of unity can be found
in [46] and references therein.
Note that, in fact, we define and enumerate the Q-operators with the help of the el-
ements of the automorphisms group of the Dynkin diagram of the affine Lie algebra
L(sl 3 ). The similar approach is used for the case of the integrable systems related to the
quantum group U q (L(sl N )) in the paper [44]. In the paper [47] Tsuboi suggested to de-
fine and enumerate Q-operators with the help of Hasse diagrams. This approach was
used then in [37, 45, 48–52].
14 We will not discuss here what is the " right " way, and only
note that for the case considered in the present paper both approaches are equivalent.
The next remark is on TT-relations. Usually one considers only three-term fusion rela-
tions of the type (3.37) and (3.38), see, for example, [39, 40]. We demonstrated that in our
case the four-term TT-relations of the type (3.41) are also useful, in particular, to prove
the quantum Jacobi–Trudi identity. It is evident from our construction that in the case of
U q (L(sl N )) one has in general (N + 1)-term TT-relations.
Among other approaches to the derivation of the TQ-relations for the " deformed " case
we would like to mention the approach based on the factorization of the Yang–Baxter
operators, see [53] and references therein, and the approach based on the concept of q-
characters [54] developed in the paper [34]. It would be interesting to generalize the
approach based on formulas for group characters [49, 50] to the " deformed " case.
Acknowledgements. This work was supported in part by the DFG grant KL 645/10-1
and by the Volkswagen Foundation. Kh.S.N. and A.V.R. were supported in part by the
RFBR grant # 13-01-00217.

APPENDIX D. DUAL REPRESENTATIONS AND MONODROMY OPERATORS
Let A be a quantum group, and R its universal R-matrix. A monodromy operator corre-
sponding to the choice of the representation ϕ for the auxiliary space and the representa-
tion ψ for the quantum space is defined as
M ϕ,ψ (ζ|η) = (ϕ ζ ⊗ ψ η )(R),
where ζ and η are spectral parameters, and the mappings ϕ ζ and ψ η are defined with
the help of equation (2.29). In fact, it is often convenient to consider the case where
ϕ is a homomorphism from the quantum group to some algebra B, see, for example,
section 2.4.1. Certainly, a representation is a partial case of such homomorphism.
Dual of a representation of A can be defined with the help of any antiautomorphism
of A. Here we use for this end the inverse of the antipode S. If ψ is a representation of A
on the vector space U, the dual representation ψ * S −1 is defined by the equation

* S −1 (a)v
